Title: Beethoven Emperor Concerto Philadelphia Orchestra Brendel, Muti 1985
Description:
Riccardo Muti conducts the Philadelphia Orchestra in performance of Beethoven‚Äôs Piano Concerto No. 5 - Emperor Concerto, Op 73 on April 25th, 1985. Alfred Brendel is the featured piano soloist. 

Thrilled to have another fantastic Muti performance on the channel, and thrilled to have even more of Alfred Brendel (see the two previous Mozart piano concertos I uploaded recently). This was recorded live off the radio by Mr. Marchant‚Äôs daughter. 


Technical Info:
Scotch 226, quarter track stereo
10.5‚Äù reel
3 3/4 IPS
Scotch 226 suffers from ‚ÄúSticky Shed Syndrome‚Äù and requires special preparation before it can be played. Unfortunately that means there can be occasional dropouts or fades - you can hear some of that in this recording. Luckily the majority of the piece is intact. More details about the preparation I took on the reel:
https://www.youtube.com/post/Ugkxh8TfxsulklceOY2PnuGTzfKIjI7Wvxiv

Title: Concerto for Bass Trombone and Orchestra (2019) ‚Äî James M. Stephenson
Description:
Riccardo Muti, conductor of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, said about James M. Stephenson's bass trombone concerto: 
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a wonderful piece, which I enjoyed more and more throughout the week. It‚Äôs truly a well-crafted piece.‚Äú
James himself writes in the program notes:
"When Charlie Vernon first told me in November of 2015 that I would be writing a new bass trombone concerto for him, he highlighted two things: 1) that it be the ‚Äúmost profound, beautiful and lasting musical event to be played on the bass trombone‚Äù (thanks, Charlie, I‚Äôll do my best‚Ä¶) and 2) that it would be ‚Äúa great story, like a book you can‚Äôt stop reading.‚Äù As I thought about these requirements, I began to think about something I consider pretty profound: life itself. Perhaps this is because at the time of the world premiere I will be 50 years old, when one starts thinking about such heavy subjects; but suffice it to say that it seemed a good time to write something that heeded the significance of life. In thinking about life, I kept coming back to the rhythms of life, and its ups and downs. This idea spurred on my initial inspiration, and I begin to feel a pulse that would inspire the entire work. A pulse, of course, fits nicely into both worlds: life and music. I coupled this early on with a rising note-motif of A-B-C, which serendipitously couples nicely with Charlie‚Äôs idea of this piece being like the reading of a book."

COMPOSER: James M. Stephenson
CONDUCTOR: Riccardo Muti
BASS TROMBONE: Charles Vernon
ORCHESTRA: Chicago Symphony Orchestra

TRACKLIST:
0:00 - I. Chapter 1
10:39 - II. Chapter 2

NOTE: This is a live performance!

Title: Elgar 'In the South' (Alassio) - Riccardo Muti / Philadelphia Orchestra
Description: Elgar's Concert Overture "In the South" was inspired by a holiday in the Italian resort of Alassio in 1903. The bad weather he and his wife endured didn't prevent him from composing this brilliant symphonic tone-poem. It is superbly played here by the glorious Philadelphia Orchestra under its then Music Director, Riccardo Muti, in a 1986 radio broadcast.

Title: LIVE recording: Berlioz Symphonie fantastique Muti, Philadelphia Orchestra 1984
Description:
The Philadelphia Symphony under direction of Riccardo Muti performs Berlioz‚Äôs Symphonie fantastique in September or October of 1984. This is a recording of a live performance broadcast on the radio and recorded to tape. No date was written on the tape box (other than 1984) so looking up Philadelphia Orchestra performances I see multiple possible dates in late September or early October of 1984. 

This is the same live broadcast from the Liszt Concerto I posted last week:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dCkOV0KjF78

A record was made of this same piece by the Philadelphia Symphony and Muti in 1984, but that record is not this recording - it does not have an audience like this live performance. Because of that, I believe this video is the only place this particular performance exists. 

Technical Info:
Realistic 44-758A, quarter track stereo
7‚Äù reel
3 3/4 IPS

Title: Mozart 34 Pf Cto 9 Entremont Philadelphia Muti Oct 1972 Live
MOZART PIANO CONCERTO No 25 C major K 503, Mitsuko Uchida, Riccardo Muti
Description:
Mitsuko Uchida is not only at home with her renditions of Beethoven but she actually started out recording and performing the full cycle of Mozart piano sonatas and concertos early on in her career. Most critics still believe that she is at her best with Mozart. One thing is certain: she keeps playing better and gets better looking with every passing year!

While the C major concerto has been slightly downplayed by musicologists, it remains not only magisterial but moving -- broad and splendid, yet keenly detailed, in the first movement; touchingly and sweet in the slow movement, with its huge, expressively vocal leaps in the solo part; and filled with gleams and shadows in the animated  finale.  Riccardo Muti is conducting the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra.
Who are the greatest Living Pianists? See: https://www.rawassertions.com/the-13-greatest-living-classical-pianists-a-bakers-dozen/

Title: Muti -"AUS ITALIEN" R. Strauss- CSO 2024  Teatro alla Scala
Muti Conducts Beethoven 9
Description:
On May 7, 1824, Beethoven shared his Ninth Symphony with the world even though he could never hear it. On May 7, 2015, celebrate the anniversary of Beethoven‚Äôs most glorious and jubilant masterpiece with Riccardo Muti and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and Chorus. An exhilarating testament to the human spirit, Beethoven‚Äôs Ninth bursts with brooding power and kinetic energy and culminates in the exultant hymn, ‚ÄúOde to Joy.‚Äù

Title: Prokofiev 3 Philadelphia Muti Oct 1972 Live
Description: This is the final work in Muti's very first guest conducting gig with Philadelphia (which was also his North American conducting debut).  The first half of this concert comprised the Mozart 34 and Entremont playing Mozart's Cto 9, separately uploaded in this channel.  There is a commercial recording of the Prokofiev 3 with Philadelphia under Muti from 1990 (nearly 20 years later) on Phillips, which supplies an interesting contrast, but I honestly don't know what to make of it due to the differing sound pictures.  I am inclined to say that the velvety sound of 1972 has had its plushness shaved down, but that could just be due to Phillips' early digital sound captured in Philadelphia's Memorial Hall (in West Fairmount Park), which is pretty harsh and congested in the tutti passages.  (Another shoutout to Messrs. Borkow and Sacks for their sound engineering in these live concerts.)  I would be interested in hearing how others perceive the changes in the Philly sound revealed by those two performances nearly two decades apart.

Title: R. Schumann - Sinfonia no. 3 op. 97 "Renana" (Berliner Philharmoniker - Riccardo Muti)
Description:
Nel settembre del 1849 Schumann si era trasferito con la famiglia a D√ºsseldorf provenendo da Dresda, dopo anni tormenti e faticosi per la composizione di Genoveva, delle Scene dal Faust, del Manfred, per il turbamento causato dalla morte di Mendelssohn, per l'inquietudine causata dalla rivoluzione del 1848-49. Il compositore aveva quasi quarant'anni, veniva a D√ºsseldorf con la carica di Direttore dei concerti, accolto con calore dall'√©lite culturale della citt√†. La Terza Sinfonia in mi bemolle, nota fin dai primi tempi con l'appellativo di "Renana". La prima esecuzione, con l'opera ancora manoscritta, avvenne nel concerto del 6 febbraio 1851 e suscit√≤ accoglienze trionfali, ripetute poco dopo a Colonia; grande impressione la Sinfonia suscit√≤ anche a Rotterdam, il 1 dicembre 1853, durante la tourn√©e olandese intrapresa da Schumann con la moglie Clara, e fino ad oggi la "Renana" √® rimasta forse la pi√π amata delle quattro Sinfonie, la pi√π unitaria e compiuta nel pensiero creativo. La Terza Sinfonia fu abbozzata e strumentata in un mese di lavoro fra il 2 novembre e il 9 dicembre 1850; il quarto movimento recava in origine la didascalia "Im Charakter der Begleitung einer feierlichen Ceremonie" ("Nel carattere di accompagnamento a una cerimonia solenne"), e con precisione ancora maggiore Schumann dichiar√≤ di essere stato influenzato dal rito con cui il vescovo di Colonia von Geissel fu innalzato alla porpora cardinalizia nel venerabile duomo, sacro alla storia tedesca e all'arte gotica. In seguito il compositore lasci√≤ cadere ogni titolo, ogni indicazione extramusicale; ma un po' come nell'Eroica di Beethoven nei confronti del generale Bonaparte, cos√¨ nella Terza di Schumann il Reno, anzi la ¬´religione del Reno¬ª come l'ha chiamata Bortolotto, resta il f√≤mite incancellabile dell'ispirazione, la regione spirituale in cui fermentano i sentimenti e le fantasie. Lo stesso Schumann confermava indirettamente questa polarit√† tutta ideale quando nel marzo 1851 scriveva all'editore Simrock di Bonn che anzich√© affidare l'opera a uno dei tanti editori sotto mano a Lipsia, aveva preferito ¬´vedere apparire proprio qui ai bordi del Reno (cio√® a Bonn) una grande opera, e proprio questa Sinfonia che forse qua e l√† rispecchia un pezzo di vita reale¬ª.
La ¬´religione del Reno¬ª schumanniana ha il suo altar maggiore nella Terza Sinfonia; lo si potrebbe circondare con tempietti votivi, quali i Lieder "Sonntags am Rhein" dell'op. 36 o "Im Rhein, im heiligen Streme" dalla Dichterliebe di Heine; ci si potrebbe aggiungere il secondo movimento della Fantasia op. 17 per pianoforte, nella stessa tonalit√† di mi bemolle e con patenti affinit√† tematiche; la comune cornice della tonalit√†, il ritmo di tre quarti, la simpatia per temi basati sulla triade fondamentale individuano un percorso che muove dall'Eroica di Beethoven, dove l'eroismo √® tutto astratto, ideale, energia pura: in Schumann l'eroe si √® concretizzato nella storia e geografia del padre Reno, del duomo di Colonia che vi si specchia, della nazione tedesca che avrebbe potuto esservi consacrata. √à soprattutto il primo movimento che non maschera il suo riferimento a Beethoven, ma pi√π nei temi che nel reale sviluppo: √® sintomatico infatti che il momento supremo di tutta la pagina, quando il tema d'apertura sfolgora nell'unisono dei quattro corni entro l'armonia di mi bemolle tenuta in pianissimo dagli altri strumenti, avvenga nella preparazione della ripresa, in un raccordo strumentale, non deputato a ricevere simili epifanie; √® un po' la mentalit√† del poema sinfonico che perfino nel "classico" Schumann viene a turbare i recinti della forma-sonata. Nel secondo movimento il Reno si spoglia dei suoi attributi mitici e indossa abiti borghesi, quelli di salubri passeggiate domenicali, allietate da robuste bevute. Il terzo movimento (Nicht schnell, Non veloce) precorre nel tenero clima espressivo il tipo dell'"Andantino" o "Allegretto" brahmsiano; il ruolo dell'Adagio, finora scoperto, √® assolto dal quarto movimento (Feierlich, Solenne) che sarebbe giusto considerare un'ampia introduzione al Finale: le arcaiche sonorit√† dei tromboni, impiegati qui per la prima volta, i temi dall'austero profilo bachiano, la densit√† dell'intreccio polifonico, caricano di solennit√† storica questa pagina, legata nella fantasia di Schumann al fascino del rito cattolico nel duomo di Colonia. Dal suo ultimo accordo, in un opaco mi bemolle minore, si sprigiona il tema in maggiore del movimento finale: che √® di vivida vena popolaresca, con toni leggeri da Scherzo mendelssohniano irrobustiti verso la fine in sonori giubili di tutta l'orchestra, in architettonica risposta all'esordio del primo movimento. (Giorgio Pestelli)

Title: Var√®se Arcana - Philadelphia Orchestra, Muti 1985
Description:
The Philadelphia Orchestra conducted by Riccardo Muti performs Edgard Var√®se‚Äôs symphonic poem Arcana on February 1st, 1985. This was recorded live off the radio onto tape by Mr. Marchant‚Äôs daughter. 

This tape required some processing to be playable, which means the quality is not as good as I would want it to be. See the technical notes below for more information. There was a taping error at the very end of the piece where another piece of music came in (radio station changed?) for half a second. I edited it out but couldn‚Äôt make it completely transparent. 

There is a big space between the end of the piece and the applause where I can picture Muti holding the baton as long as possible to evoke the dramatic end of a dramatic piece. It‚Äôs a neat moment.

I've created a Muti playlist since I have a few of his performances on the channel now:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLhut5IVLHxGawzTegUoK6pEd-ADT8_70u

Technical Info:
Ampex 1800, quarter track stereo
7‚Äù reel
3 3/4 IPS
This tape suffers from sticky shed syndrome which means it has to be specially treated before being played. That process can result in some audio problems unfortunately. With this track there are some balance issues where the left channel is quieter than the right. I tried to adjust for this but there is only so much you can do. For more about the sticky shed treatment see my post here:
https://www.youtube.com/post/Ugkxh8TfxsulklceOY2PnuGTzfKIjI7Wvxiv

Title: Liszt Piano Concerto No 2: Campanella, Muti Philadelphia Orchestra 1984
Description:
Michele Campanella is the featured piano soloist in a Philadelphia Orchestra performance of Franz Liszt‚Äôs Concerto for Piano and Orchestra No. 2 in A major, S.125 in September or October of 1984. Riccardo Muti conducts. This is a recording of a live performance broadcast on the radio and recorded to tape. No date was written on the tape box (other than 1984) so looking up Philadelphia Orchestra performances I see multiple possible dates in late September or early October of 1984. 

This performance does not appear to be on record or on YouTube so I‚Äôm happy to have apparently surfaced a lost recording. 

Technical Info:
Realistic 44-758A, quarter track stereo
7‚Äù reel
3 3/4 IPS
There were some pretty loud scratchy radio crackling noises early in the performance that I managed to mostly remove, but some quiet ones are still there. There is tape degradation apparent in the first minute or so of the recording but it goes away pretty quickly and the rest sounds pretty great, especially for being recorded at the slower speed of 3 3/4 inches per second.
